G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts and omissions giving rise to this action occurred at Defendant's place of business located in Quincy, Norfolk County, Massachusetts.

Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.raw_text: Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640, 646 (1990)
Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.proposition: As the owner and operator of a business open to the public, Defendant had a duty of care to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition for patrons, including Plaintiff, and to warn of or remedy any hazards of which they knew or should have known.
Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an employer’s potential duty to protect an employee from criminal acts of third parties and turns entirely on foreseeability in the employer‑employee context, not on premises liability duties owed by a business open to the public to its patrons. The court expressly notes it is not deciding whether the employer‑employee relationship creates special duties, and it does not discuss the general duty of a landowner or business proprietor toward members of the public. Therefore it does not support the claimed proposition about a business’s duty of care to patrons on its premises.
Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that the defendants may be held liable under either of two theories. First, the plaintiffs argue that the defendants voluntarily assumed a duty to protect Foley against attacks by third parties. … Second, the plaintiffs claim that the employer-employee relationship between the BHA and Foley gave rise to a duty to protect Foley against attacks by third parties. Under either theory, in order for liability to be imposed, the plaintiffs are required to prove that Ferris’s attack on Foley was foreseeable.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: As the owner and operator of a business open to the public, Defendant had a duty of care to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition for patrons, including Plaintiff, and to warn of or remedy any hazards of which they knew or should have known.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion focused on the abandonment of rigid invitee/licensee classifications and criticizing the continued separate treatment of trespassers. It does not itself set out or apply a specific duty of care for business owners toward patrons, nor does it discuss maintaining premises in a reasonably safe condition or warning of known or knowable hazards. While the main Mounsey decision is indeed about premises liability and duties of care, nothing in this particular quoted passage clearly supports the detailed proposition stated.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.proposition:
Defendant breached its duty of care by:
   a. Allowing water and ice to remain on the tile floor for an extended period without cleaning it up;
   b. Failing to warn patrons, including Plaintiff, by placing wet floor signs or other indicators of the hazardous condition; and
   c. Failing to train or instruct its employees to immediately address and remedy unsafe conditions.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.support_reasoning: The case addresses a landowner’s duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition and, specifically, the duty to remedy even open and obvious dangers. It does not involve or discuss premises liability based on water/ice on a tile floor, failure to post wet floor signs, or failure to train employees to address such conditions; there are no employees or business‑premises facts at issue. Thus, while it supports a general duty-to-remedy principle, it does not support the specific negligence theories listed in the proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ … A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg….”

Sarkisian v. Concept Rest., Inc., 471 Ma.raw_text: Sarkisian v. Concept Rest., Inc., 471 Mass. 679, 681 (2015)
Sarkisian v. Concept Rest., Inc., 471 Ma.proposition: Defendant knew or reasonably should have known about the hazardous condition caused by the spilled water and ice, as its employee created the condition and its staff admitted to avoiding the puddle, thus failing to act with the reasonable care required under similar circumstances.
Sarkisian v. Concept Rest., Inc., 471 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does not state that the defendant or its employees actually created the specific hazardous condition or that staff admitted to avoiding a particular puddle. Instead, the court holds that the nightclub had notice of the inherent risk of spills due to its mode of operation and that the mode-of-operation doctrine satisfies the notice requirement without proof of actual or constructive notice of this particular spill. Thus, the case supports a broader foreseeability/mode-of-operation notice theory, not the specific proposition that defendant knew or should have known of this specific puddle because its employee created it and staff avoided it.
Sarkisian v. Concept Rest., Inc., 471 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “For the foregoing reasons, we conclude that summary judgment was improperly granted and that the defendant had notice of the inherent risks associated with its chosen mode of operating its dance floor… Considering the evidence in the light most favorable to the plaintiff… the reasonable inference is that a spilled beverage produced the wet surface on which the plaintiff slipped… Whether the defendant exercised reasonable care to protect patrons from such spillage is a question for the jury.”

O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204 (.proposition: Plaintiff reasonably relied on the expectation that Defendant’s premises would be kept in a reasonably safe condition and did not reasonably foresee the hazard until she had already slipped.
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204 (.support_reasoning: The case holds that the danger (diving into the shallow end) was open and obvious and therefore negated any duty to warn; it does not recognize any reasonable reliance by the plaintiff on the premises being kept reasonably safe, nor does it find that the hazard was unforeseeable to the plaintiff until after he slipped. Instead, the court emphasizes that a person of average intelligence would recognize the risk and that the plaintiff himself knew of the danger. Thus, the opinion contradicts rather than supports the claimed proposition.
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204 (.relevant_excerpt: “Landowners are relieved of the duty to warn of open and obvious dangers on their premises because it is not reasonably foreseeable that a visitor exercising (as the law presumes) reasonable care for his own safety would suffer injury from such blatant hazards… We conclude that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool is open and obvious to a person of average intelligence, the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law.”

Scott v. Garfield, 454 Mass. 790, 793 (2.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered physical injuries, emotional distress, lost income, and medical expenses.
Scott v. Garfield, 454 Mass. 790, 793 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses that Scott suffered serious physical injury and incurred medical expenses, and applies standard tort and warranty principles including recovery of medical costs and other compensatory damages. However, the case is not about pleading or proving that a plaintiff suffered physical injuries, emotional distress, lost income, and medical expenses as a direct and proximate result of a defendant’s negligence; rather, it concerns a lawful visitor’s ability to recover for personal injuries under an implied warranty of habitability and related evidentiary issues. It therefore does not function as authority for the specific negligence-damages proposition as phrased.
Scott v. Garfield, 454 Mass. 790, 793 (2.relevant_excerpt: “On July 20, 2002… As he stood up, the railing gave way and Scott fell to the ground, seriously injuring his shoulder… The jury returned special verdicts in favor of Scott, on his claims of negligence and breach of the implied warranty of habitability… Because judgment entered for Scott on his claim of breach of the implied warranty of habitability (rather than his claim for negligence), he recovered $450,000, the full amount of damages found by the jury with no reduction for the jury’s finding of comparative negligence.”
